Federal Court
Hughes, J.
February 14, 2007.
Counsel:
John B. Laskin and Jennifer Conroy, for the applicants;
Carol Hitchman and Olga Kalinina, for the respondent, Pharmascience.
Solicitors of Record:
Torys, LLP, for the applicants;
Hitchman & Sprigings, for the respondent, Pharmascience.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.

[1]
Hughes, J.
: These Reasons and Order deal with a motion made before me on Monday, February 12, 2007, at the outset of a hearing of two other motions, to permit the Applicants to file as part of their Record in the lengthier motion dealing with Canadian Patent 2,355,493 an affidavit of Navrish Dhanao affirmed December 11, 2006. At the hearing I indicated that the motion would be dismissed and the Dhanoa affidavit not admitted in evidence with brief reasons to follow. These are those reasons.

[2]
Two proceedings T-768-06 and T-899-06 have essentially proceeded together. They are both proceedings brought under the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations, SOR/93-133 as amended (NOC Regulations). The Applicants are the same, the Minister of Health is a Respondent in both. Both include the same patents. The other Respondent, a generic drug company known as a second party in the NOC Regulations, is different in each, Cobalt Pharmaceuticals Ltd. in T-768-06 and Pharmascience Inc.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> -06.

[3]
In each proceeding a schedule for the filing of affidavits and cross-examination was agreed to by the parties and made the subject of a Court Order. The cross-examination of one of the Pharmascience witnesses had been completed before Counsel for the Applicant, through apparent inadvertence, noticed that the Affidavit of Dhanoa, which had not yet been affirmed, was not part of the Record. Counsel for the Applicants sought the consent of the Counsel for the Respondents, Cobalt and Pharmascience, as to the filing of the affidavit and that was refused. Hence the motion.

[4]
Applicants Counsel concedes that the Dhanoa affidavit is late, it was tendered after the date for the filing of affidavits had past, set by the undertakings between Counsel, subsequently embodied in an Order. It was tendered after cross-examination of an opposite partys witnesses had begun. The only excuse offered as to lateness was inadvertence of Applicants Counsel.

[6]
In respect of the present matter it is clear from paragraph 5 of the Affidavit of Zimmerman supporting the Applicants motion, that the Dhanoa Affidavit was earlier contemplated, and in fact it was only Counsels inadvertence that precluded it from being filed in time. This is a factor supporting a refusal to allow it in now.

[7]
As to the usefulness of the Dhanoa Affidavit, Dhanoa is a student-at-law in the offices of the Applicants solicitors. Dhanoa apparently telephoned a publishing house and received from them information as to the date of publication of a scientific article by Zhang. Dhanoa also went to CISTI, a Canadian document delivery service and procured a copy of a sticker bearing an apparent date of receipt of the Zhang article by that service. This evidence is hearsay. No reason was given as to why direct evidence from the publisher or from CISTI could not have been procured. Cross-examination of Dhanoa would be largely futile.

[8]
While Rule 81 permits hearsay evidence to be adduced in affidavits an adverse inference can be drawn from a failure to provide evidence from those having personal knowledge.

[9]
Further, the Dhanoa evidence is from a student-at-law in the office of the solicitors and Counsel for the Applicants. Rule 82 of this Court forbids a solicitor from arguing a matter based on his or her affidavit without leave of the Court. In  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  the Federal Court of Appeal held that it was improper for a solicitor to proceed to argue a motion where a member of his or her firm had given an affidavit. While the Court has, as permitted by Rule 82, allowed a solicitor to argue a matter where the affidavit is non-controversial, if it is other than that, the affidavit is inadmissible or other Counsel should argue the matter.

[10]
Here, the affidavit, being hearsay and questionable as to admissibility given it was from a member of Applicants counsels firm, the probative value would be low. It must be remembered that what is under consideration is the evidence tendered and not the point to be made from the evidence. If the evidence is weak then, regardless of the point to be argued from it, there is less reason to permit it to be filed late.

[11]
In any event, the point to be made, the publication date of the Zhang article, at the end of the day, made no difference to the arguments as presented in oral argument on the other motions.

[12]
Therefore, the motion to permit the filing and addition to the Record of the Dhanoa affidavit is dismissed with costs.
ORDER

[13]
FOR THE REASONS PROVIDED HEREIN:
THIS COURT ORDERS that:
1. The motion to permit the filing and adding to the Record of the Dhanoa affidavit is dismissed; and
2. The Respondent, Pharmascience, is entitled to its costs.
[End of document]

statutes: Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations, SOR/93-133 as amended (NOC Regulations)
legal_issues: Admissibility of evidence submitted after a deadline established by procedural rules and court order.
Standard for granting leave to file late evidence, considering factors such as prejudice, usefulness, and interests of justice.
Admissibility of hearsay evidence in affidavit form and the implications of failing to provide direct evidence.
Restrictions on solicitor participation and the admissibility of evidence presented through firm members.
The impact of weak or questionable evidence on a motion to admit it outside of established deadlines.
Allocation of costs associated with a motion.
factual_background: Two related proceedings (T-768-06 and T-899-06) were initiated under the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations.
The Applicants and the Minister of Health are common respondents in both proceedings.
Cobalt Pharmaceuticals Ltd. and Pharmascience Inc. are the other respondents, one in each proceeding.
A schedule for filing affidavits and cross-examination was established by court order.
After cross-examination of a Pharmascience witness was completed, Applicants' counsel discovered an unfiled affidavit from Navrish Dhanao.
Applicants' counsel sought consent from Cobalt and Pharmascience to file the Dhanao affidavit, but consent was refused.
The Dhanao affidavit was submitted after the deadline for filing affidavits had passed.
The stated reason for the late filing was inadvertence by Applicants' counsel.
The Dhanao affidavit contains information obtained through a phone call to a publishing house and a document received from CISTI regarding the publication date of a scientific article by Zhang.
The information in the affidavit is hearsay, and direct evidence from the publisher or CISTI was not provided.
Dhanao is a student-at-law employed by the Applicants' solicitors.
The publication date of the Zhang article was a point the Applicants intended to establish with the affidavit.

Applicants: The Dhanoa affidavit, though late, should be admitted as it would be of assistance to the Court in making its final determination.
The lateness of the affidavit was due to counsel’s inadvertence.
The affidavit contains evidence regarding the publication date of a scientific article by Zhang, which is relevant to the case.
The affidavit, despite being hearsay, is admissible under Rule 81.
Respondents: The Dhanoa affidavit is late, filed after the deadline for affidavits and after cross-examination of witnesses had begun.
The evidence presented in the affidavit is hearsay, as it is based on information received from a publishing house and CISTI, and direct evidence from those sources was not obtained.
The affidavit is from a student-at-law within the Applicants’ counsel’s firm, which raises concerns under Rule 82 regarding a solicitor arguing based on their firm’s affidavit without leave of court.
The publication date of the Zhang article, the subject of the affidavit, ultimately did not affect the arguments presented in oral argument.

court_analysis: The court denied the applicants' motion to file a late affidavit (Dhanao affidavit) because it was filed after the agreed-upon and court-ordered deadline, and the only justification offered was counsel's inadvertence.

The court applied a five-part test established in prior case law to determine whether to allow the late filing, considering anticipation of the evidence, its usefulness to the court, potential prejudice from refusal, the interests of justice, and potential for delay. The court found the factors weighed against allowing the affidavit.
The court found the affidavit was contemplated earlier but not filed due to counsel's inadvertence, weighing against its admission.

The court determined the evidence presented in the affidavit was largely hearsay – information obtained from a publishing house and CISTI – and questioned why direct evidence from those sources wasn't obtained, noting an adverse inference could be drawn from the failure to do so. It also found cross-examination of the affiant (a student-at-law) would be largely futile.

The court referenced Rule 82, which restricts solicitors from arguing based on their own affidavits without leave, and a Federal Court of Appeal decision finding it improper for a solicitor to argue a motion based on an affidavit from a member of their firm. Because the affidavit was from a member of the applicant's counsel's firm and of questionable admissibility, the court found its probative value low.
The court emphasized that even if a legal point could be made from the evidence, the weakness of the evidence itself diminished the reason to allow its late filing.

The court ultimately found the information in the affidavit (the publication date of a scientific article) was irrelevant to the arguments presented in oral argument, further supporting the decision to deny the motion.
final_outcome: The motion to permit the filing and adding to the Record of the Dhanoa affidavit is dismissed.
The Respondent, Pharmascience, is entitled to its costs.
